questions.text: The reciprocity theorem is applicable to circuits that are:

choices.text: Linear, bilateral, and contain a single source.

questions.text: A "Chebyshev" filter is known for having a steeper roll-off than a Butterworth filter, at the cost of:
The "Early voltage" of a BJT is a parameter that models the:

choices.text: Slope of the output characteristic curves in the active region.
Breakdown voltage of the collector-base junction.
Forward voltage drop of the base-emitter junction.

questions.text: A "thyristor" or "Silicon-Controlled Rectifier" (SCR) is a semiconductor device that acts like a:

choices.text: Latching switch (once turned on, it stays on until the current drops below a holding value)

questions.text: An op-amp "instrumentation amplifier" is a differential amplifier configuration optimized for high input impedance, high CMRR, and precise gain. It is typically built using:

choices.text: A combination of op-amps and discrete transistors.

questions.text: The "unity-gain frequency" ($f_T$) of a transistor is the frequency at which the:

choices.text: Short-circuit common-emitter current gain ($\beta$) becomes unity.

questions.text: What is a "hazard-free" design in digital logic?

choices.text: A design that is guaranteed to be free of static and dynamic hazards.
A design that uses only AND and OR gates.
A design that is implemented using a ROM.
A design that has been formally verified.

questions.text: In an FPGA, the primary logic element that implements combinational and sequential logic is the:

choices.text: Configurable Logic Block (CLB) or Logic Array Block (LAB)

questions.text: A "Wallace Tree" is a hardware implementation of a:

choices.text: Fast multiplier that reduces the number of partial product addition stages.

questions.text: "SIMD" (Single Instruction, Multiple Data) is a class of parallel computers in Flynn's taxonomy that is characterized by:

choices.text: A single processor executing a single stream of instructions on a single stream of data.
Multiple processors executing different instructions on different data.
A single control unit dispatching a single instruction to multiple processing units that operate on different data.
Multiple processors executing the same instruction on the same data.

questions.text: In C++, \texttt{std::mutex} provides mutual exclusion. What does \texttt{std::lock_guard} provide?

choices.text: A RAII-style mechanism that acquires a mutex on construction and releases it on destruction, preventing deadlocks from forgetting to unlock.
A way to lock multiple mutexes at once.

questions.text: What is "template metaprogramming" in C++?

choices.text: A technique using templates to generate code and perform computations at compile time.
A feature for handling runtime polymorphism.

questions.text: In TCP, what is the role of the "Urgent Pointer" field?

choices.text: It indicates that the packet should be processed with high priority by routers.
It is used in conjunction with a flag to indicate a location in the segment data where "urgent" data ends.
It specifies the size of the receive window.
It is used to terminate a connection immediately.

questions.text: A problem is "undecidable" if:

choices.text: No algorithm can be constructed that will always lead to a correct yes-or-no answer.
It takes exponential time to solve.
The solution is difficult to verify.

questions.text: A "Bloom filter" is a probabilistic data structure used to test whether an element is a member of a set. It is known for being space-efficient but can have:

choices.text: False positives (may say an element is in the set when it is not).
False negatives (may say an element is not in the set when it is).
Both false positives and false negatives.

questions.text: In operating systems, a "futex" is a feature of the Linux kernel that allows for:

choices.text: Fast userspace locking with kernel assistance only when contention occurs.

questions.text: What is the core idea of "Aspect-Oriented Programming" (AOP)?

choices.text: To increase the coupling between modules.
To allow for the modularization of cross-cutting concerns (like logging or security) that span across multiple objects.
It is another name for object-oriented programming.

questions.text: In machine learning, "boosting" is an ensemble technique that:

choices.text: Trains multiple models in parallel on different subsets of the data.
Trains models sequentially, where each subsequent model attempts to correct the errors of its predecessor.
Uses a single, very deep neural network.

questions.text: What is "critical chain project management" (CCPM)?

choices.text: A method that focuses on managing the resources required to execute project tasks and uses buffers to manage uncertainty.
Another name for the waterfall model.

questions.text: An engineer's ethical duty of "continuing professional development" means they must:

choices.text: Only work in their original area of expertise.
Keep current with the knowledge and skills in their field.

questions.text: In a BJT, the "alpha cutoff frequency" ($f_\alpha$) is generally much higher than the "beta cutoff frequency" ($f_\beta$) because:

choices.text: The common-base configuration has a higher gain.
The transit time of charge carriers across the base is the primary limiting factor, and its effect is less pronounced on $\alpha$ than on $\beta$.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a "finite state machine with output" (like Mealy or Moore machines)?

choices.text: To act as a language recognizer.
To act as a transducer, converting an input sequence into an output sequence.
To store large amounts of data.

questions.text: What is "copy elision" in C++?

choices.text: A compiler optimization technique that eliminates unnecessary copying of objects.
A way to explicitly copy an object.
A feature of the C++ preprocessor.

questions.text: A "speculative execution" vulnerability like Spectre exploits:

choices.text: A bug in the operating system's kernel.
The side effects of a CPU's predictive execution to leak information from protected memory.

questions.text: What is "Multipath TCP" (MPTCP)?

choices.text: A proposed extension to TCP that allows a connection to use multiple paths to maximize resource usage and increase redundancy.
A security layer on top of TCP.
An older, obsolete version of TCP.

questions.text: The "Rice's Theorem" in computability theory states that:

choices.text: All non-trivial semantic properties of programs are undecidable.
Any regular language can be described by a regular expression.

questions.text: A "persistent data structure" is a data structure that:

choices.text: Is stored on a hard disk.
Always preserves the previous version of itself when it is modified.

questions.text: In an operating system, a "light-weight process" (LWP) is:

choices.text: A process with a very small memory footprint.
A kernel-level abstraction that is scheduled by the kernel and that user-level threads can be mapped to.
A process that does not perform I/O.

questions.text: What is a "feature toggle" or "feature flag" in software development?

choices.text: A technique that allows parts of a program to be turned on or off at runtime without deploying new code.

questions.text: The "Composite" design pattern is a structural pattern that:

choices.text: Lets you compose objects into tree structures to represent part-whole hierarchies.
Ensures a class has only one instance.

questions.text: In machine learning, what is a "convolutional neural network" (CNN) particularly good at?

choices.text: Processing grid-like data, such as images.

questions.text: The "To-Complete Performance Index" (TCPI) based on the Budget at Completion (BAC) is calculated as:
An engineer's ethical responsibility to avoid "deceptive acts" means they must not:

choices.text: Misrepresent their qualifications or falsify data.

questions.text: In an op-amp, the "virtual ground" concept at the inverting input of a negative feedback configuration means that:

choices.text: The input is physically connected to ground.
The op-amp drives the inverting input to the same potential as the non-inverting input (which is often ground), but no current flows into the op-amp.
The output is always at ground potential.

questions.text: The primary difference between a "binary semaphore" and a "mutex" is that:

choices.text: A mutex can be acquired and released by different threads, while a semaphore must be released by the same thread that acquired it.
A semaphore can be acquired and released by different threads, while a mutex must be released by the same thread that acquired it.
A mutex can have a count greater than 1.

questions.text: What is the function of the \texttt{volatile} keyword in C?

choices.text: It tells the compiler to perform aggressive optimizations on the variable.
It informs the compiler that the value of the variable may change by means outside the control of the current program, preventing certain optimizations.
It allocates the variable in a special memory region.

questions.text: In networking, what is "path MTU discovery"?

choices.text: The process of finding the shortest path to a destination.
A standardized technique to determine the maximum transmission unit (MTU) size on the network path between two hosts.
A way to discover all the routers on a path.

questions.text: What is the relationship between the complexity classes P and NP?

choices.text: P is a subset of NP.
NP is a subset of P.

questions.text: The "Command" design pattern encapsulates a request as an object, which is useful for:

choices.text: Implementing undoable operations, queues, and logging.
Adding new functionality to an object.

questions.text: "Gradient clipping" is a technique used when training neural networks to:

choices.text: Prevent the problem of exploding gradients by capping the gradient's value.
Add more layers to the network.

questions.text: What is "constructive cost model" (COCOMO)?

choices.text: A software cost estimation model based on lines of code and various cost drivers.

questions.text: An engineer is asked to sign off on a project they did not personally supervise. Ethically, they should:

choices.text: Refuse to sign off unless they have personally reviewed the work and are competent to verify its adequacy.
Ask someone else to sign off.
Sign off but add a disclaimer.

questions.text: A "clipper" circuit is used to:

choices.text: Cut off or limit the portions of a signal that are above or below a certain reference level.

questions.text: What is "static timing analysis" (STA) in digital design?

choices.text: A simulation of the circuit to check its functionality.
A method of verifying the timing of a digital circuit without requiring simulation, by checking all paths for setup and hold time violations.
An analysis of the circuit's power consumption.
A way to generate a test pattern.

questions.text: In C++, what is an "lvalue" and an "rvalue"?

choices.text: An lvalue is a value on the left of an assignment; an rvalue is on the right.
An lvalue is an expression that refers to a memory location; an rvalue is typically a temporary value.
An lvalue is a local variable; an rvalue is a global variable.

questions.text: What is "BGP route flapping"?

choices.text: A desirable condition where routes are updated quickly.
A situation where a BGP router repeatedly advertises a route as available, then unavailable, causing instability.
A way to load balance traffic.

questions.text: What is the "PCP" (Post's Correspondence Problem)?

choices.text: A famous undecidable problem in computability theory.
A problem solvable in polynomial time.

questions.text: In software development, what is a "canary release"?

choices.text: The final, stable release of a product.
A technique to reduce the risk of introducing a new software version in production by slowly rolling out the change to a small subset of users.
A release with many known bugs.

questions.text: What is the "no free lunch" theorem in machine learning?

choices.text: It states that all machine learning models are equally good.
It states that there is no one model that works best for every problem; the performance of a model is specific to the problem.
It states that machine learning models require a large amount of data.
It is a theorem about reinforcement learning.

questions.text: In project management, what is a "phase-gate" review?

choices.text: A review at the end of a project phase in which a decision is made to continue, modify, or terminate the project.

questions.text: A "differential amplifier" is a circuit that amplifies the:
What is "quine" in computing?

choices.text: A program that produces a copy of its own source code as its only output.

questions.text: In the C++ standard library, what is the difference between \texttt{std::vector} and \texttt{std::list}?

choices.text: \texttt{vector} provides fast random access but slow insertion/deletion in the middle; \texttt{list} provides slow random access but fast insertion/deletion anywhere.
There is no major difference in performance.

questions.text: What is a "remote procedure call" (RPC)?

choices.text: A protocol that allows a program on one computer to execute a procedure on another computer without the programmer needing to code the details for the remote interaction.
A way to call functions within the same program.
A system call to the operating system.

questions.text: The "CAP theorem" in distributed systems states that it is impossible for a distributed data store to simultaneously provide more than two out of which three guarantees?
The "Bridge" design pattern is a structural pattern whose intent is to:

choices.text: Decouple an abstraction from its implementation so that the two can vary independently.
Ensure a class has only one instance.

questions.text: In machine learning, what is a "recurrent neural network" (RNN) suitable for?

choices.text: Processing sequential data where the order of information is important, like time series or natural language.

questions.text: What is a "contingency reserve" in project management?

choices.text: The budget allocated for the entire project.
The budget or time set aside for identified risks ("known unknowns").
The budget set aside for unidentified risks ("unknown unknowns").
The profit margin of the project.

questions.text: An engineer is reviewing a design by a non-engineer that is technically sound but inefficient. The engineer's ethical duty is to:

choices.text: Reject the design outright because it was not made by an engineer.
Provide constructive feedback and suggest improvements, while acknowledging the sound aspects of the design.
Approve the design as-is to avoid conflict.

questions.text: What is a "soft real-time system"?

choices.text: A system where missing a deadline is a catastrophic failure.
A system where missing a deadline results in a degradation of performance but not a total failure.
A system that does not have deadlines.

questions.text: An ideal op-amp is configured as an inverting amplifier with an input resistor of $10 \, \mathrm{k}\Omega$ and a feedback resistor of $150 \, \mathrm{k}\Omega$. If the input voltage is $+0.5 \, \mathrm{V}$, what is the output voltage?
A "carry-lookahead" logic block has inputs $P_i = A_i \oplus B_i$ (propagate) and $G_i = A_i \cdot B_i$ (generate). What is the expression for the carry-out of the second bit, $C_2$?

choices.text: $G_1 + P_1 \cdot G_0 + P_1 \cdot P_0 \cdot C_{-1}$ (assuming $C_{-1}$ is carry-in to the first bit)

questions.text: A system has a 2-level page table. The virtual address is 32 bits. The page size is $4 \, \mathrm{KB}$. The page directory index uses 10 bits and the page table index uses 10 bits. What is the size of a single page table for the second level? (Assume each entry is 4 bytes).

You are designing a reliable protocol over an unreliable channel. The probability of a single packet being lost is $p$. What is the probability that a packet needs to be transmitted exactly 3 times to be successfully received?
What is the parametric equation for a circle centered at $(x_c, y_c)$ with radius $r$?

A system has 3 processes ($P_1$, $P_2$, $P_3$) and a single resource with 12 instances. $P_1$ requires 10, $P_2$ requires 4, and $P_3$ requires 9. At time $t$, $P_1$ holds 5, $P_2$ holds 2, and $P_3$ holds 2. Is this state safe or unsafe?

choices.text: Safe, sequence $\langle P_2, P_1, P_3 \rangle$ exists.
Safe, sequence $\langle P_2, P_3, P_1 \rangle$ exists.
Unsafe, as no process can be guaranteed to finish.

questions.text: A project has $BAC = \$1000$, $AC = \$600$, $EV = \$400$. What is the To-Complete Performance Index (TCPI) required to finish on budget? ($TCPI = (BAC - EV) / (BAC - AC)$)
Consider the grammar: $S \to S + S \mid S * S \mid (S) \mid a$. Why is this grammar problematic for parsing?
What is the difference between \texttt{TRUNCATE TABLE} and \texttt{DELETE FROM TABLE} in SQL?

choices.text: \texttt{TRUNCATE} is faster and cannot be rolled back; \texttt{DELETE} is slower, can be rolled back, and can have a \texttt{WHERE} clause.
\texttt{TRUNCATE} removes the table structure; \texttt{DELETE} only removes the data.

questions.text: What is a "race condition"?

choices.text: A situation where the outcome of a computation depends on the non-deterministic relative timing of events.

questions.text:
What language does the Turing Machine described below recognize? ($q_0$ = start, $q_f$ = final, $B$ = blank) \\
$\delta(q_0, 0) \to (q_0, 0, R)$ \\
$\delta(q_0, 1) \to (q_0, 1, R)$ \\
$\delta(q_0, B) \to (q_f, B, R)$

choices.text: The language of all binary strings $\{0, 1\}^*.
The language of strings with an equal number of 0s and 1s.

questions.text: In the context of IPv4, what is a "supernet"?

choices.text: A network with a very large number of hosts.
An aggregation of multiple smaller subnets into a single larger network, summarized by a single routing entry.

questions.text: In machine learning, the "F1 Score" is the harmonic mean of:
What is the primary trade-off in choosing the order (size of $d$) of a B-Tree?

choices.text: A larger order increases the height of the tree.
A larger order reduces the height of the tree (fewer disk I/Os) but increases the cost of operations within a node.
The order does not affect performance.
A smaller order is always better.

questions.text: A file system uses an inode with 10 direct pointers, one single indirect, one double indirect, and one triple indirect pointer. If a block is $8 \, \mathrm{KB}$ and a block address is 4 bytes, what is the theoretical maximum file size?
What is the "Chain of Responsibility" design pattern?

choices.text: A pattern that creates a chain of receiver objects for a request, allowing each receiver a chance to handle it.
A pattern for adding functionality to an object.
A pattern for defining a communication channel.
The first \texttt{printf} has undefined behavior (wrong format specifier for integer division result).

questions.text: A 4-bit synchronous binary counter is in state 0110. What will be the state after the next clock pulse?

A project has a critical path A-B-C. Activity A has a duration of 5 days, B has a duration of 10 days, and C has a duration of 3 days. What is the latest start time for activity B if the project must finish in 18 days?
